The civil war in Sudan, ongoing for approximately 16 months, has resulted in severe humanitarian consequences, including a massive hunger crisis and widespread displacement. Over 6,000 homes have been completely destroyed, with more than 10,000 damaged, leading to the displacement of nearly eight million Sudanese. Approximately half of these internally displaced individuals are being accommodated by friends, family, or strangers, highlighting the critical role of local communities in hosting those affected by the conflict [1][2]. The conflict has triggered the largest refugee crisis globally, with over ten million people displaced or forced to flee, many multiple times, and nearly 15,000 deaths reported [3].

The humanitarian situation is dire, with more than six million people facing food insecurity across Darfur and over 25 million, or about half the population, in a similar situation across the country. More than a dozen areas in Sudan are either experiencing or at risk of famine, with the World Food Programme (WFP) and other aid organizations warning of an imminent famine due to the civil war, displacement, and humanitarian access constraints [4][5][3][6][7]. Reports indicate that deaths have already occurred, particularly among infants and young children suffering from acute malnutrition [8].

Local and national humanitarian organizations in Sudan are playing a significant role in addressing the needs of displaced populations. Emergency rooms, charitable organizations, and local committees are actively providing daily meals and medical care to those affected by the conflict. Communal kitchens have stepped up to offer meals and emotional support to hundreds of thousands in Khartoum [9][10]. Approximately 150 humanitarian organizations across Sudan, including national NGOs, have reached nearly 8 million people with some form of humanitarian aid since January [10]. However, these organizations face numerous challenges, including administrative and bureaucratic hurdles imposed by warring parties, threats such as arrests, prolonged investigations, restrictions on movement, and systematic targeting. At least 22 Sudanese national aid workers have been killed, and at least 34 have been wounded or injured. Female aid workers are at high risk of sexual violence, which has been weaponized by warring factions [9][10]. The lack of safety and security is a major concern, with international humanitarian law not being respected, leading to potential attacks at any time or place without warning [11]. Restrictions on civil society organizations and grassroots committees have severely hampered their ability to gather information, assess situations, and call for assistance. Communication blackouts further limit capabilities and hinder access to funding via banking applications [9]. The Sudan humanitarian appeal, seeking US$2.7 billion, is only 33 percent funded, constraining and limiting the response efforts of national NGOs. Obstruction of aid delivery by militias is also a problem, with main supply routes often inaccessible, preventing the delivery of necessities like food and medical supplies [10][11].

The Rapid Support Forces (RSF) Civil Administration in South Darfur State has welcomed the opening of the Adre border crossing. The head of the state's civil administration, Mohamed Ahmed Hassan, announced RSF's readiness to establish strong partnerships and facilitate the work of humanitarian organizations that come to provide services and assistance to the residents [12]. The reopening of the Adre border crossing, after a six-month closure, is considered critical for preventing famine from spreading across Sudan. The first World Food Programme (WFP) food supplies for communities in Darfur crossed the Adre border from Chad, carrying essential items for 13,000 people in Kereneik, West Darfur [13][14][15][16][17]. This move aims to facilitate humanitarian aid for civilians displaced by Darfur's violence, with WFP Executive Director Cindy McCain emphasizing the need for all border crossings to be open daily to avoid widespread starvation [13][14][15][16][17].

The ongoing siege by the Rapid Support Forces (RSF) in El Fasher, the provincial capital of North Darfur State, has led to critical living conditions, with famine looming in the city. Famine conditions were confirmed in Zamzam displacement camp near Al Fasher, where people were reported to be starving to death. The city has been under RSF siege since last May, and the five-month blockade has made living conditions critical [18][19]. Access to basic services, such as safe water, is an enormous challenge in Zamzam camp, where all wells were out of service due to a lack of fuel because the area is surrounded by the RSF. Only two of the eight water wells in the camp are currently operating, and there is a struggle to bring water to the camp due to clashes, artillery shelling, and lack of funding [20].

To sustain the flow of food and nutrition assistance into Sudan, the World Food Programme (WFP) is implementing several strategies. WFP is using alternative and longer routes, such as through Chad's Tine crossing into North Darfur, and long, dangerous routes from Port Sudan that cross battle frontlines and areas controlled by different militia groups to reach communities in Darfur. A newly re-opened route is also being utilized for swift movement of supplies [21][22][23][24]. WFP is scaling up food assistance, aiming to support up to 8.4 million people by the end of the year in 14 areas either in famine or at risk of famine, largely located in Darfur, Kordofan, Khartoum, and Gezira [21][22][23][24][25]. In Khartoum, where truck access is difficult, WFP has started using alternative ways of delivering assistance, including mobile money, cash vouchers, and support for community kitchens to provide hot meals [26]. UN humanitarians continue to engage with Sudanese authorities to facilitate additional trucks for a constant supply of humanitarian goods [25].

Floods are impacting the delivery of humanitarian aid in Sudan by frustrating the flow of aid. More than 50 trucks carrying an estimated 4,800 metric tons of World Food Programme (WFP) food and nutrition assistance are stuck in various locations across Sudan, unable to move towards their final destinations due to flooded and impassable roads. The rainy season exacerbates the already devastating situation, as floods force more people from their homes, increase humanitarian needs, and cut off communities from vital assistance. Heavy rains have destroyed key bridges and made it extremely difficult for aid convoys to pass through muddy, flooded roads. Nearly 143,000 people in 12 of Sudan's 18 states have been affected by the floods, with 50 people killed and at least 27,000 people displaced. Waterborne diseases such as typhoid and cholera also pose a threat to malnourished children and women [27][23]. Some forecasts warn that flooding could surpass the historic 2020 floods that hit Khartoum [27].

The Rapid Support Forces (RSF) Civil Administration in South Darfur State has expressed support for the reopening of the Adre border crossing, a move welcomed by the head of the state's civil administration, Mohamed Ahmed Hassan. He emphasized RSF's readiness to forge strong partnerships and facilitate the work of humanitarian organizations aiming to provide services and assistance to residents[12]. This reopening is particularly significant given the severe humanitarian crisis resulting from the ongoing civil war in Sudan, which has persisted for approximately 16 months[3]. The conflict has led to a dire hunger crisis, with over six million people facing food insecurity in Darfur and more than 25 million, or about half the country's population, in a similar situation nationwide[4][6]. The World Food Programme (WFP) and other aid organizations have warned of an imminent famine, attributing it to the civil war, displacement, and constraints on humanitarian access[5][3]. Reports indicate that deaths have already occurred, especially among infants and young children suffering from acute malnutrition[8].

The conflict has also triggered the largest global refugee crisis, displacing over ten million people, many of whom have been forced to flee multiple times[3]. The power struggle has resulted in nearly 15,000 deaths[3]. To address these challenges, the WFP is implementing several strategies to sustain the flow of food and nutrition assistance into Sudan. These include using alternative and longer routes, such as through Chad's Tine crossing into North Darfur[21][22][23][24], and navigating long, dangerous routes from Port Sudan that cross battle frontlines and areas controlled by different militia groups to reach communities in Darfur[21][22][24]. A newly re-opened route is also being utilized for the swift movement of supplies[23]. The WFP aims to scale up food assistance to support up to 8.4 million people by the end of the year in 14 areas either in famine or at risk of famine, primarily located in Darfur, Kordofan, Khartoum, and Gezira[21][22][23][24][25]. In Khartoum, where truck access is difficult, the WFP has started using alternative methods of delivering assistance, including mobile money, cash vouchers, and support for community kitchens to provide hot meals[26]. UN humanitarians continue to engage with Sudanese authorities to facilitate additional trucks for a constant supply of humanitarian goods[25].

However, the delivery of humanitarian aid is being severely impacted by floods, which have frustrated the flow of aid[23]. More than 50 trucks carrying an estimated 4,800 metric tons of WFP food and nutrition assistance are stuck in various locations across Sudan, unable to move towards their final destinations due to flooded and impassable roads[27]. The rainy season exacerbates the already devastating situation, as floods force more people from their homes, increase humanitarian needs, and cut off communities from vital assistance[27]. Heavy rains have destroyed key bridges and made it extremely difficult for aid convoys to pass through muddy, flooded roads[27]. Nearly 143,000 people in 12 of Sudan's 18 states have been affected by the floods, with 50 people killed and at least 27,000 people displaced[27]. Waterborne diseases such as typhoid and cholera also pose a threat to malnourished children and women[27]. Some forecasts warn that flooding could surpass the historic 2020 floods that hit Khartoum[27].

The reopening of the Adre border crossing, which had been closed since February, is seen as critical for preventing famine from spreading across Sudan[13][14]. The crossing was reopened by Sudanese authorities after a six-month closure, and it was announced on August 15 that the Adre border crossing would be opened for the first inter-agency cross-border transport of vital humanitarian aid through this corridor since February[13][14][19][15]. The first WFP food supplies for communities in Darfur crossed the Adre border from Chad, with WFP trucks carrying sorghum, pulses, oil, and rice for 13,000 people in Kereneik, West Darfur[13][14][16][17]. The UN Secretary-General commended the Sudanese authorities on August 17 for reopening the Adre border crossing, recognizing it as a direct route for humanitarian aid[15]. The Adre border crossing was announced to be open for a three-month period[28].

Famine is looming in the city[18], and famine conditions were confirmed in Zamzam displacement camp near Al Fasher, where people were reported to be starving to death[18][19]. The city has been under RSF siege since last May, and the five-month blockade has made living conditions critical[18]. Access to basic services, such as safe water, is an enormous challenge in Zamzam camp[20]. All wells at the camp were out of service due to a lack of fuel because the area is surrounded by the RSF[20]. Only two of the eight water wells in the camp are currently operating, and there is a struggle to bring water to the camp due to clashes, artillery shelling, and lack of funding[20].

Local and national humanitarian organizations in Sudan are playing a crucial role in addressing the needs of displaced populations, with approximately 150 organizations, including national NGOs, reaching nearly 8 million people with some form of humanitarian aid since January[10][29]. These efforts include providing daily meals and medical care through emergency rooms, charitable organizations, and local committees, as well as communal kitchens offering meals and emotional support to hundreds of thousands in Khartoum[9][10]. Despite these efforts, roughly half of the nearly eight million Sudanese internally displaced by the conflict are being accommodated by friends, family, or strangers, underscoring the significant role of local communities in hosting[2].

However, these organizations face numerous challenges, including obstacles imposed by warring parties such as administrative and bureaucratic hurdles[9]. Humanitarian workers and volunteers are threatened with arrests, prolonged investigations, restrictions on movement, systematic targeting, and confiscation of aid[9]. At least 22 Sudanese national aid workers have been killed, and 34 wounded or injured while on duty, with female aid workers at high risk of sexual violence, weaponized by warring factions[9][10]. The lack of safety and security is a major concern, as international humanitarian law is not respected, leading to potential attacks at any time or place without warning[11]. Restrictions on civil society organizations and grassroots committees severely hamper their ability to gather information, assess situations, and call for assistance, while communication blackouts further limit capabilities and hinder access to funding via banking applications[9]. The Sudan humanitarian appeal, seeking US$2.7 billion, is only 33 percent funded, constraining the response efforts of national NGOs[10]. Additionally, militias obstruct aid delivery, and main supply routes can be inaccessible, preventing the delivery of necessities like food and medical supplies, with the rainy season further complicating access due to heavy rains and flash floods[10][11].

The health crisis in Sudan is exacerbated by a cholera outbreak, with the World Health Organization (WHO) reporting 11,327 cases and 316 fatalities[30]. The outbreak, attributed to poor environmental conditions and contaminated drinking water, is predominantly in eastern Sudan's Kassala, with officially declared outbreaks in Kassala and several other states[30][31]. The Sudanese Ministry of Health, in cooperation with WHO and UNICEF, has implemented measures to address the outbreak, including a cholera vaccination campaign targeting 51,000 people in Wad El Helew[32][33]. However, vaccines quickly ran out due to the high number of displaced individuals, prompting calls for additional supplies[33]. The ongoing conflict has also led to an increase in dengue and meningitis cases[30].

The conflict has had a devastating impact on civilian infrastructure, with over 75% of health facilities in conflict-affected states rendered non-functional[34][35]. Since April 2023, 88 attacks on healthcare, including on health facilities, ambulances, transport, assets, patients, and health workers, have been verified, resulting in 55 deaths and 104 injuries[34][35]. Specific instances of airstrikes impacting health facilities include the bombing of a major hospital in El Daein, killing at least 15 people, and an airstrike on a vaccination center west of El Daein Teaching Hospital[36][37]. In Al-Koma, a clinic's lack of necessary equipment contributed to the deaths of a woman and her four children admitted with injuries after airstrikes[37].

The ongoing siege by the Rapid Support Forces (RSF) in El Fasher, the provincial capital of North Darfur State, has led to critical living conditions, with famine looming in the city and confirmed famine conditions in Zamzam displacement camp near Al Fasher, where people are reported to be starving to death[18][19]. The five-month blockade has made living conditions critical, with access to safe water being an enormous challenge in Zamzam camp[18][20]. All wells at the camp were out of service due to a lack of fuel, with only two of the eight water wells currently operating, and there is a struggle to bring water to the camp due to clashes, artillery shelling, and lack of funding[20].

The ongoing civil war in Sudan, which has persisted for approximately 16 months, has led to severe humanitarian consequences, including a massive hunger crisis and widespread displacement. Over 25 million people, or about half the population, face food insecurity, with more than six million affected in Darfur alone. The World Food Programme (WFP) and other aid organizations have warned of an imminent famine, attributing it to the civil war, displacement, and constraints on humanitarian access. Reports indicate that deaths have already occurred, particularly among infants and young children suffering from acute malnutrition[4][5][3][6][8][7].

Local and national humanitarian organizations in Sudan have been pivotal in addressing the needs of displaced populations, with approximately 150 organizations, including national NGOs, reaching nearly 8 million people with some form of humanitarian aid since January. These efforts are supported by emergency rooms, charitable organizations, and local committees that provide daily meals and medical care to those affected by the conflict. Communal kitchens in Khartoum have also stepped up to offer meals and emotional support to hundreds of thousands[2][9][10][29]. Despite these efforts, the organizations face numerous challenges, including administrative and bureaucratic hurdles imposed by warring parties, threats to humanitarian workers, and a lack of safety and security. At least 22 Sudanese national aid workers have been killed, and 34 wounded or injured, with female aid workers at high risk of sexual violence. Restrictions on civil society organizations and communication blackouts further limit their capabilities, while the Sudan humanitarian appeal remains only 33 percent funded, constraining response efforts[9][10][11].

The conflict has triggered the largest refugee crisis globally, with over ten million people displaced or forced to flee, many multiple times. The power struggle has resulted in nearly 15,000 deaths, with Sudanese army airstrikes in North Darfur causing civilian casualties and damage to infrastructure and livestock. In Al-Koma, a woman and her four children were killed by airstrikes, and over 150 livestock were lost. Eyewitnesses reported that only civilian areas were hit, with no Rapid Support Forces (RSF) gathering points affected[3][40][37].

Humanitarian organizations face additional challenges in delivering aid to famine-stricken areas due to delays in access, perilous routes crossing battle frontlines, and obstruction by warring parties. The severe autumn rainy seasons have disrupted major roads and destroyed bridges, further hindering aid delivery. However, the reopening of the Adre border crossing has significantly influenced these efforts. Announced on August 15, the crossing allows for the first inter-agency cross-border transport of vital humanitarian aid since February. WFP trucks carrying food supplies for 13,000 people in West Darfur crossed the border, and UNHCR also participated in the first inter-agency convoy. The reopening is considered critical for preventing famine from spreading across Sudan, with the UN Secretary-General commending the move as a direct route for humanitarian aid[13][14][28][19][15][16][17].

The conflict has devastated civilian infrastructure, rendering over 75% of health facilities in conflict-affected states non-functional. Since April 2023, 88 attacks on healthcare, including on facilities, ambulances, and health workers, have been verified, resulting in 55 deaths and 104 injuries. The destruction of power, water, and sanitation infrastructure has increased the risk of diseases and contributed to famine risk. Specific instances of airstrikes impacting health facilities include the bombing of a major hospital in El Daein, killing at least 15 people, and an airstrike on a vaccination center west of El Daein Teaching Hospital. Patients and medics evacuated the hospital after it was bombed, and in Al-Koma, a clinic's lack of necessary equipment contributed to the deaths of a woman and her four children[34][35][36][37].

Efforts to address the crisis include a roadmap initiative presented to the leadership of the Sudanese Armed Forces (SAF) 22nd Infantry Division and the RSF in West Kordofan. The military parties have expressed strong support for the initiative, although formal talks have not yet occurred. The RSF Civil Administration in South Darfur State has welcomed the opening of the Adre border crossing and expressed readiness to establish strong partnerships to facilitate humanitarian work[42][12].

Local and national humanitarian organizations in Sudan are playing a crucial role in addressing the needs of displaced populations, with approximately 150 organizations, including national NGOs, reaching nearly 8 million people with some form of humanitarian aid since January[10][29]. These efforts include providing daily meals and medical care through emergency rooms, charitable organizations, and local committees, as well as communal kitchens offering meals and emotional support to hundreds of thousands in Khartoum[9][10]. Additionally, about half of the nearly eight million Sudanese internally displaced by the conflict are being accommodated by friends, family, or strangers, underscoring the significant role of local communities in hosting[2].

However, these organizations face numerous challenges, including obstacles imposed by warring parties such as administrative and bureaucratic hurdles[9]. Humanitarian workers and volunteers are threatened with arrests, prolonged investigations, restrictions on movement, systematic targeting, and confiscation of aid[9]. At least 22 Sudanese national aid workers have been killed, and 34 have been wounded or injured while on duty[10]. Female aid workers are at high risk of sexual violence, which has been weaponized by warring factions[9]. The lack of safety and security is a major concern, with international humanitarian law not being respected, leading to potential attacks at any time or place without warning[11]. Restrictions on civil society organizations and grassroots committees have severely hampered their ability to gather information, assess situations, and call for assistance, while communication blackouts further limit capabilities and hinder access to funding via banking applications[9]. The Sudan humanitarian appeal, seeking US$2.7 billion, is only 33 percent funded, constraining and limiting the response efforts of national NGOs[10]. Obstruction of aid delivery by militias is also a problem, with main supply routes often inaccessible, preventing the delivery of necessities like food and medical supplies[10][11]. The rainy season further complicates access due to heavy rains and flash floods[11].

Floods are significantly impacting the delivery of humanitarian aid in Sudan, with more than 50 trucks carrying an estimated 4,800 metric tons of World Food Programme (WFP) food and nutrition assistance stuck in various locations due to flooded and impassable roads[27][23]. The rainy season exacerbates the situation, as floods force more people from their homes, increase humanitarian needs, and cut off communities from vital assistance[27]. Heavy rains have destroyed key bridges, making it extremely difficult for aid convoys to pass through muddy, flooded roads[27]. Nearly 143,000 people in 12 of Sudan's 18 states have been affected by the floods, with 50 people killed and at least 27,000 people displaced[27]. Waterborne diseases such as typhoid and cholera pose a threat to malnourished children and women[27]. Some forecasts warn that flooding could surpass the historic 2020 floods that hit Khartoum[27].

The Federal Emergency Operations Centre is addressing the cholera epidemic through an extensive campaign in cooperation with state health ministries, the World Health Organisation (WHO), and UNICEF[33]. Despite these efforts, the challenges posed by the floods remain significant, with no specific measures clearly stated to address them.

This reopening is considered critical for preventing famine from spreading across Sudan, with the UN Secretary-General commending the Sudanese authorities for this move[13][14][28][15]. 14.context: title: First WFP trucks cross Sudan's reopened Adre border with food for communities at risk of famine  content: First WFP trucks cross Sudan's reopened Adre border with food for communities at risk of famineWorld Food Programme21 August 2024ROME -- The first WFP food supplies destined for desperate communities in Sudan's Darfur have crossed the Adre border from Chad, after it was reopened by the Sudanese authorities following a six-month closure.WFP trucks, carrying sorghum, pulses, oil and rice destined for 13,000 people at risk of famine in Kereneik, West Darfur, crossed on Tuesday evening. WFP has food and nutrition supplies for around 500,000 people ready to move swiftly through the newly re-opened route. "The re-opening of the Adre crossing is critical for the effort to prevent famine from spreading across Sudan, and it must now stay in use. I want to acknowledge all parties for taking this vital step to help WFP get lifesaving aid to millions of people in desperate need," said WFP Executive Director Cindy McCain.
